pr_title: Fix crash caused by getting flutter view id with .join()

timeline.message: Fix crash caused by getting flutter view id with .join()

timeline.bodyText:
It looks like get() may also block the thread until the value is ready?
I believe the underlying issue here is that we're using clocking calls and this code path can be called from the event thread. I suspect what we need to do is to move to a non-blocking call (which may be something like .whenComplete()?), and then use that to determine the display refresh rate, and return the value as a future.
(Java futures definitely have a much larger API surface area than the Dart variant)
timeline.author: devoncarew

replies.bodyText: The issue with whenComplete is that it returns a CompletableFuture<T> . In this case T is a String because that is the value we expect from getFlutterViewId. However, we need to return CompletableFuture<Double> for displayRefreshRate.
replies.author: kenzieschmoll

replies.bodyText: You may try creating a CompletableFuture<Double> foo at the start of the method, starting the future work to get the flutterViewId, and return the foo completable future. When you have the flutter view ID, you can then request the display rate. Once you have a value for that you should be able to call foo.complete(displayRefreshRate).
replies.author: devoncarew

replies.bodyText: I think I found a way around this by returning outside of whenComplete. PTAL.
replies.author: kenzieschmoll

timeline.message: Merge branch 'master' of github.com:flutter/flutter-intellij into flutterViewId

timeline.bodyText: If t is not null here, should we instead complete displayRefreshRate with the defaultRefreshRate?
timeline.author: devoncarew

replies.bodyText: I think you either want to use thenApplyAsync() and exceptionally(), or use whenComplete(). It looks like whenComplete gives you both the value, if it completes nornally or the exception if it fails.
replies.author: devoncarew

timeline.message: Removed both uses of exceptionally in favor of whenComplete throwable.

timeline.bodyText: This needs an else statement, otherwise when t != null we'll call displayRefreshRate.complete() twice.
